definition: to plunder/to pillage/to forcibly take
see 搶風|抢风[qiang1 feng1]
to fight over/to rush/to scramble/to grab/to rob/to snatch
to seize/to take away forcibly/to wrest control of/to compete or strive for/to force one's way through/to leave out/to lose

sentences.english: Frist, carrying the lethal weapon to grab and turning into the crime of robbing.
sentences.chinese: 第一，携带凶器抢夺转化为抢劫犯罪。

sentences.english: Siblings become enemies, fighting over assets that are left.
sentences.chinese: 所遗家产，成为兄弟反目，争相抢夺。

sentences.english: The victorious army despoiled the city of many priceless treasures.
sentences.chinese: 战胜的军队抢夺了那城市的许多无价之宝。

sentences.english: Then he can rob his house.
sentences.chinese: 必先摆捆住那壮士，才可以抢夺他的家。

sentences.english: Villa is a drum ahead into the market, snatching empty when.
sentences.chinese: 别墅市场更是击鼓疾进，抢夺空当。

sentences.english: May be an aerodyne to scramble.
A government that robs Peter to pay Paul can always depend on the support of Paul.
sentences.chinese: 抢夺彼得支付保罗的政府可能总取决于保罗支持。

sentences.english: Therefore, each group and opened the battles the reign of terror.
sentences.chinese: 为此，各个集团又展开了腥风血雨的殊死抢夺。

sentences.english: Other leisure activities: Several other leisure activities represent serious competition for social board and card games.
sentences.chinese: 一些其它休闲活动也在抢夺桌游和卡牌游戏人口。

sentences.english: After Plagiarist snatched Genuine's Intellectual Property Rights, he walk away quickly.
sentences.chinese: 剽窃者抢夺正版的智慧财产权后，快步扬长而去。
摩押人哪，我们现在去抢夺财物吧。

sentences.english: Many towns MOBS while disorderly plunder the rulers food.
sentences.chinese: 很多城镇的乱民都趁乱抢夺官府的粮食。

sentences.english: The idea of plunder, murder, and regicide !
sentences.chinese: 是的，抢夺谋杀杀死沙皇的思想。

sentences.english: One boy is playing football , one boy goes to snatch.
sentences.chinese: 获胜者是那个能够抢夺到对方魔杖的人。

sentences.english: The seizing crime is between robbery and steal.
sentences.chinese: 抢夺罪是介于抢劫罪与盗窃罪之间的一种罪。

sentences.english: The act of robbing someone at gunpoint.
sentences.chinese: 持枪相威胁，抢夺他人财物的行为。

definition: to snatch (esp related to a robbery)
to fight over/to scramble for
to covet/to long for/to lust after
to plunder/to rob
to snatch away
to seize (the strategic high ground)
see 搶風|抢风[qiang1 feng1]
to fight over/to rush/to scramble/to grab/to rob/to snatch
to loot a burning house/to profit from sb's misfortune (idiom)
to rob/looting
to seize/to take away forcibly/to wrest control of/to compete or strive for/to force one's way through/to leave out/to lose
to take for one's own/to expropriate
to seize/to capture/to wrest control of
to plunder/to loot/robbery/pillage
looting
to hog/to keep everything for oneself
to take back (forcibly)/to recapture/to win back
